titleInfo.title: Heat Transfer Fundamentals and Enhancement at Component and System Levels

mods:mods.abstract: This doctoral dissertation pertains to the study of heat transfer, fluid-structure-thermal interactions, buoyancy-driven flows, and the numerical modeling techniques needed to systematically study the different problems related to these topics. The research carried out is based on the numerical models and simulations. It will become apparent that there are two main topics discussed in this dissertation. The first, thought of as a component-level study of the heat transfer and physics related to or influencing the enhancement of heat transfer or stability of the thermal response of the component. Two chapters are dedicated to this topic in which the fluid-structure-thermal interactions of a flexible (passively) flapping flag are studied. The effects of the structure material parameters as well as the fluid parameters are studied 1) within the scope of mixed convection, and 2) under the influence of a nearby free-surface. The latter, although not directly involving heat transfer, considers the flow problem encountered in phase-changing system such as the boiling of a fluid, aided by a passive agitator such as a flapping flag. The second topic addressed in the dissertation adopts a system-level approach, specifically examining heat transfer in a thermally- buoyant fluid system confined within a fully enclosed cavity. Often, differentially heated cavities are encountered in practical engineering systems in which the heat transfer must be enhanced, reduced or used to alter the flow structure within the cavity. The simplest iteration of this problem, the classical differentially heated cavity, is considered and some new contributions are made to this topic. Furthermore, a layer of complexity is added to more closely resemble the conditions typically found in practical engineering situations. This is done through the development of a novel conjugate boundary condition which is applied to the system. The heat transfer and flow stability of the system is studied in depth using this novel technique. A significant contribution of this dissertation lies in the development and application of numerical modeling techniques to simulate and analyze heat transfer in complex systems. High-fidelity computational simulations serve as a virtual laboratory, enabling the exploration of parameters are challenging or impractical to replicate experimentally. The numerical models are validated ensuring their reliability in capturing the intricate details of the physical problems studied here. The outcomes of this research aims to advance the fundamental understanding of heat transfer In summary, this dissertation offers a numerical exploration of heat transfer, fluid-structure-thermal- interactions, buoyancy-driven flows (natural convection), aiming to advance the fundamental understanding of heat transfer.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Mechanical Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Juan C. Ordoñez, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Kourosh Shoele, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Mark Sussman, University Representative; William Oates, Committee Member; Wei Guo, Committee Member.
